raw_text:
Peer-to-peer nets 'here to stay'
 
 Peer-to-peer (P2P) networks are here to stay, and are on the verge of being exploited by commercial media firms, says a panel of industry experts.
 
 Once several high-profile legal cases against file-sharers are resolved this year, firms will be very keen to try and make money from P2P technology. The expert panel probed the future of P2P at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas earlier in January. The first convictions for P2P piracy were handed out in the US in January. William Trowbridge and Michael Chicoine pleaded guilty to charges that they infringed copyright by illegally sharing music, movies and software. Since the first successful file-sharing network Napster was forced to close down, the entertainment industry has been nervous and critical of P2P technology, blaming it for falling sales and piracy. But that is going to change very soon, according to the panel.
 
 The music and film industries have started some big legal cases against owners of legitimate P2P networks - which are not illegal in themselves - and of individuals accused of distributing pirated content over networks. But they have slowly realised that P2P is a good way to distribute content, said Travis Kalanick, founder and chairman of P2P network Red Swoosh, and soon they are all going to want a slice of it. They are just waiting to come up with "business models" that work for them, which includes digital rights management and copy-protection standards.
 
 But, until the legal actions are resolved, experimentation with P2P cannot not happen, said Michael Weiss, president of StreamCast Networks. Remembering the furore around VCRs when they first came out, Mr Weiss said: "Old media always tries to stop new media. "When they can't stop it, they try to control it. Then they figure out how to make money and they always make a lot of money." Once the courts decided that the VCR in itself was not an illegal technology, the film studios turned it into an extremely lucrative business. In August 2004, the San Francisco-based US Court of Appeals ruled in favour of Grokster and StreamCast, two file-sharing networks. The court said they were essentially in the same position that Sony was in the 1980s VCR battle, and said that the networks themselves could not be deemed as illegal.
 
 P2P networks usually do not rely on dedicated servers for the transfer of files. Instead it uses direct connections between computers - or clients. There are now many different types of P2P systems than work in different ways. P2P nets can be used to share any kind of file, like photos, free software, licensed music and any other digital content. The BBC has already decided to embrace the technology. It aims to offer most of its own programmes for download this year and it will use P2P technology to distribute them. The files would be locked seven days after a programme aired making rights management easier to control. But the technology is still demonised and misunderstood by many. The global entertainment industry says more than 2.6 billion copyrighted music files are downloaded every month, and about half a million films are downloaded a day. Legal music download services, like Apple iTunes, Napster, have rushed into the music marketplace to try and lure file-sharers away from free content. Sales of legally-downloaded songs grew tenfold in 2004, with 200 million tracks bought online in the US and Europe in 12 months, the IFPI reported this week. But such download services are very different from P2P networks, not least because of the financial aspect.
 
 There are several money-spinning models that could turn P2P into a golden egg for commercial entertainment companies. Paid-for-pass-along, in which firms receive money each time a file is shared, along with various DRM solutions and advertiser-based options are all being considered. "We see there are going to be different models for commoditising P2P," said Marc Morgenstern, vice president of anti-piracy firm Overpeer.
 
 "Consumers are hungry for it and we will discover new models together," agreed Mr Morgenstern. But many net users will continue to ignore the entertainment industry's potential controlling grip on content and P2P technology by continuing to use it for their own creations. Unsigned bands, for example, use P2P networks to distribute their music effectively, which also draws the attention of record companies looking for new artists to sign. "Increasingly, what you are seeing on P2P is consumer-created content," said Derek Broes, from Microsoft. "They will probably pay an increasing role in helping P2P spread," he said. Looking into P2P's future, file sharing is just the beginning for P2P networks, as far as Mr Broes is concerned. "Once some of these issues are resolved, you are going to see aggressive movement to protect content, but also in ways that are unimaginable now," he said. "File-sharing is the tip of the iceberg."
llama3.2:1b: Peer-to-peer nets 'here to stay' with commercial media firms exploiting them after several high-profile legal cases.

Industry experts agree P2P networks will become a significant revenue source for entertainment companies once legal issues are resolved, and they can develop business models such as digital rights management and copy-protection standards.
Some entertainment companies have already started using legitimate P2P networks to distribute content, including the BBC which plans to offer most of its own programs for download this year.
llama3.2:3b: Peer-to-peer networks are expected to be exploited by commercial media firms soon, with legal cases against file-sharers nearing resolution.
Firms will look to monetize P2P technology through digital rights management and copy-protection standards, including paid-for-pass-along models.
The BBC aims to use P2P for content distribution, while unsigned bands and consumers continue to use it for their own creations, which may lead to new business models.
Industry experts predict aggressive protection of content and unimaginable measures will follow once issues are resolved, with file-sharing being just the beginning.
gemma2:2b: Peer-to-peer (P2P) networks are inevitable and poised for commercial success.
Legal cases against file sharers are leading firms like music and film companies to see P2P's potential for revenue generation.
Legal battles are ongoing, but as soon as they resolve, P2P can be exploited commercially.
P2P networks facilitate sharing of any digital content from files to software.
The industry is moving away from piracy with a focus on legal downloading through platforms like iTunes and the rise of streaming services.
Many people continue to use P2P for personal purposes like distributing music by unsigned bands.
As P2P evolves, its role will expand beyond just file sharing, potentially leading to secure content delivery and protection strategies.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Peer-to-peer (P2P) networks continue to gain traction and may soon be exploited by commercial media firms due to high-profile legal cases against file-sharers.
Experts agree P2P technology has a bright future as it can distribute content without violating copyright laws.
The entertainment industry is already taking steps to make money from their P2P business, while many others are exploring new ways of sharing files through networks like Netflix.
Some P2P models involve paid-for-pass-along where users earn revenue each time they share a file and may include various DRM solutions, advertiser-based options, or other monetization methods.
Consumers are increasingly turning to P2P for their own content creation as they gain control over how it is shared.
P2P networks have the potential to increase consumer-created content sharing by giving file-sharing services new tools to help them protect their content from unauthorized use and infringement.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Industry experts predict P2P networks will soon be exploited by commercial media firms following legal cases against file-sharers and piracy crackdowns.
Despite initial resistance from the entertainment industry, they acknowledge P2P's potential for distributing content effectively and are exploring business models to capitalize on this technology.
However, experimentation with P2P cannot occur while unresolved legal issues remain, according to Michael Weiss of StreamCast Networks.
qwen2.5:3b: Peer-to-peer (P2P) networks are here to stay and will be exploited by commercial media firms once legal cases against file-sharers are resolved.
Despite initial concerns from the entertainment industry, P2P technology can now be used for content distribution, with some companies already experimenting.
The San Francisco Court of Appeals ruled in favor of Grokster and StreamCast, allowing them to continue as long as they follow digital rights management standards.
Music and film industries have launched legal cases against P2P networks and their users, aiming to develop new business models such as paid file sharing and ad-based distribution.
However, many users are using P2P for creating and sharing original content, which could influence its future development beyond simple file sharing.
opencoder:1.5b: The given text is a summary of several key points.
It summarizes the idea that peer-to-peer networks should be here to stay, and are on the verge of being exploited by commercial media firms.
After several high-profile legal cases, P2P technology will make money from it.
The first conviction for P2P piracy were handed out in the US in January.
A case was settled in Las Vegas, and then the industry has been nervous and critical of P2P technology for falling sales and piracy.

The music and film industries started some big legal cases against owners of legitimate P2P networks - which are not illegal in themselves - and have slowly realised that P2P is a good way to distribute content.
But, as per the panel, until the legal actions are resolved, experimentation with P2P cannot not happen.
smollm:1.7b: The text summary above provides a concise and accurate overview of the key ideas and details from the original text on the topic of Peer-to-Peer (P2P) networks.

Here's how it can be summarized:

1.
**Key idea**: P2P is here to stay, and is on the verge of being exploited by commercial media firms.

**Legal cases against owners of legitimate P2P networks**: The entertainment industry has started some big legal cases against owners of legitimate P2P networks, blaming them for distributing pirated content over networks.

**Business models**: There are several money-spinning models that could turn P2P into a golden egg for commercial entertainment companies, including paid-for-pass-along, in which firms receive money each time a file is shared, and various DRM solutions and advertiser-based options.

**Consumer use of P2P**: Unsigned bands are using P2P networks to distribute their music effectively, and this trend will probably continue as more artists discover the benefits of sharing content on P2P.
**Aggressive movement to protect content**: The industry is moving aggressively to protect content from P2P file-sharing, but in ways that are unimaginable now.
This could include new DRM solutions, ad blockers, and other technologies to prevent piracy.

**Key players**: The text mentions several key players involved in the P2P ecosystem, including Red Swoosh (StreamCast Networks), Overpeer (a company that provides DRM solutions for P2P networks), and Microsoft (which is working on a new P2P platform).
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Once several high-profile legal cases against file-sharers are resolved this year, firms will be very keen to try and make money from P2P technology.
The expert panel probed the future of P2P at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas earlier in January.
The first convictions for P2P piracy were handed out in the US in January.
William Trowbridge and Michael Chicoine pleaded guilty to charges that they infringed copyright by illegally sharing music, movies and software.
Since the first successful file-sharing network Napster was forced to close down, the entertainment industry has been nervous and critical of P2P technology, blaming it for falling sales and piracy.

The music and film industries have started some big legal cases against owners of legitimate P2P networks — which are not illegal in themselves — and of individuals accused of distributing pirated content over networks.
But they have slowly realized that P2P is a good way to distribute content, said Travis Kalanick, founder and chairman of P2P network Red Swoosh, and soon they are all going to want a slice of it.
They are just waiting to come up with "business models" that work for them, which includes digital rights management and copy-protection standards.
Once the legal actions are resolved, experimentation with P2P cannot not happen, said Michael Weiss, president of StreamCast Networks.
Remembering the furore around VCRs when they first came out, Mr. Weiss said: "Old media always tries to stop new media."
When they can't stop it, they try to control it.
Then they figure out how to make money and they always make a lot of money.
Once the courts decided that the VCR in itself was not an illegal technology, the film studios turned it into an extremely lucrative business.
P2P networks usually do not rely on dedicated servers for the transfer of files.
Instead, it uses direct connections between computers — or clients.
There are now many different types of P2P systems than work in different ways.
P2P nets can be used to share any kind of file, like photos, free software, licensed music and any other digital content.
The BBC has already decided to embrace the technology.
It aims to offer most of its own programmes for download this year and it will use P2P technology to distribute them.
The files would be locked seven days after a programme aired making rights management easier to control.
But the technology is still demonised and misunderstood by many.
The global entertainment industry says more than 2.6 billion copyrighted works were lost in the move from P2P to traditional media.
The industry continues to fight over the status of P2P technology, even as it gains traction with platforms like FileSharers (Napster) and others.
The music and film industries are involved with P2P, especially companies like Red Swoosh.
They want P2P networks to provide "business models" — digital rights management or ad-supported profit models.
The industry is still in the legal gray area, so P2P technology hasn't yet become mainstream.
File-sharing tech is gaining traction due to its flexibility — clients can share any type of file directly without dedicated servers.
This could lead to more apps and tools for users but has been heavily discounted by consumers.
The BBC's move to offer content via P2P aims to make rights management easier, but it remains controversial.
tinyllama:1.1b: In summary, Peer-to-peer (P2P) networks are here to stay and will continue to evolve into successful models for distributing content, as per the expert panel probed at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas earlier this year.
Legal cases against P2P owners have started, but they are just waiting to come up with "business models" that work for them, including digital rights management and copy-protection standards.

However, the entertainment industry is still trying to figure out how to make money from P2P technology, with various models such as paid-for-pass-along, P2P content creation for consumers, and DRM solutions and advertiser-based options being explored.
Despite consumer resistance towards file-sharing networks, the future looks promising for P2P technology in providing new forms of distribution for creative content.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Summarizing this text: Peer-to-peer networks, which allow users to share files like music and videos over the internet, have been popular for some time but could become even more influential in the future.
Entertainment industries are hesitant about using P2P technology, as they worry it will disrupt their business models.

However, with legal cases against file-sharers being resolved, P2P networks may be adopted by commercial media firms for a variety of reasons, including providing content distribution and allowing users to share creations freely.
phi:2.7b: The text discusses how peer-to-peer (P2P) networks have been controversial and criticized by the entertainment industry for causing piracy.
However, it suggests that P2P technology may soon be exploited by commercial media firms to make money through legal means such as digital rights management and copy protection standards.
Until then, experimentation with P2P is still possible, and the entertainment industry has already started exploring ways to monetize it.
orca-mini:3b: Peer-to-peer networks are here to stay and will be exploited by commercial media firms, according to industry experts.
Legal cases against P2P network owners are expected to be resolved soon, and once they are, experimentation with P2P technology cannot happen until then.
However, even after the legal cases, P2P networks will continue to be used for consumer-created content.
hermes3:3b: P2P networks set to continue, commercial media firms looking to exploit them after legal cases against piracy resolve.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: P2P networks are here to stay and will soon be exploited by commercial media firms after several high-profile legal cases against file-sharers are resolved, according to a panel of industry experts.
The music and film industries have started big legal cases against owners of legitimate P2P networks and individuals accused of distributing pirated content over these networks.

These cases make it clear that P2P is a good way to distribute content, so they're waiting to come up with "business models" that work for them, including digital rights management and copy-protection standards.
Different money-spinning models could turn P2P into a golden egg for commercial entertainment companies.
The BBC has decided to embrace the technology and aims to offer most of its own programmes for download this year using P2P technology.
However, many net users will continue to ignore the entertainment industry's potential controlling grip on content and use P2P for their own creations.

While the entertainment industry has long blamed P2P for piracy and declining sales, legal battles against file-sharers and P2P network owners are gradually shifting perspectives.
Industry experts predict that once legal issues are resolved, companies will seek ways to monetize P2P through business models incorporating digital rights management and copy protection.
Historically, new media technologies, like VCRs, faced resistance before becoming profitable, and P2P is expected to follow a similar path.
Some organizations, like the BBC, are already adopting P2P for content distribution.
Meanwhile, legal music download services have grown, but they differ from P2P in financial structure.
Various monetization strategies, such as paid-for-pass-along and advertiser-based models, are being explored.
Despite industry control efforts, many users continue to leverage P2P for independent content distribution, including unsigned musicians.
Experts believe file-sharing is just the beginning, with P2P poised for broader applications in the future.
stablelm2:1.6b: Peer-to-peer (P2P) networks are predicted by industry experts to continue staying in use and may soon be exploited by media firms for commercial purposes after several high-profile legal cases against file-sharers are resolved this year.

Although initially criticized by the entertainment industry for falling sales and piracy, P2P technology is now being explored as a good way to distribute content with business models like digital rights management and copy-protection standards.
Once the legal actions are resolved, experimentation with P2P will happen.
The global entertainment industry states that over 2.6 billion copyrighted music files are downloaded every month, while about half a million films are downloaded daily.
Legal music download services like Apple iTunes have grown tenfold in recent months.
However, such services differ significantly from P2P networks as they rely on dedicated servers for file transfer and financial models may emerge soon.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Peer-to-peer (P2P) networks are set to become a lucrative sector for commercial media firms, according to an industry panel at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.
This shift will occur as high-profile legal cases against file-sharers conclude this year, leading entertainment companies to explore P2P technology's potential for content distribution.
Despite initial criticism, these industries have begun recognizing the benefits of P2P in distributing legitimate media.
P2P networks operate independently without dedicated servers, relying on direct connections between computers.
They can share various digital files, including music, movies, software, and photos.
The BBC has already adopted P2P technology to distribute some programs, with files locked after a specified period for easier rights management.
The entertainment industry acknowledges that over 2.6 billion copyrighted music files are downloaded monthly and about half a million films daily via P2P networks.
However, they plan to develop business models incorporating digital rights management (DRM), copy-protection standards, paid-for-pass-along services, and advertiser-based options.

While legal download services like Apple iTunes have grown in popularity, offering legitimate content for purchase, P2P networks remain distinct due to their emphasis on free distribution and consumer-created content.
Unsigned bands and independent artists utilize P2P networks effectively, catching the attention of record labels seeking new talent.
As legal issues surrounding P2P are resolved, the technology is expected to expand beyond file sharing into more sophisticated protection measures for copyrighted materials.
Industry experts predict that P2P will play an increasingly significant role in content distribution and rights management, marking it as a transformative force in the entertainment landscape.
